utterances: And at that point, we saw Helen Bowers from the Park Service.
And I described her at the time and still do as just an angel.
It was - she just seemed to be in such shape and she was just so beautiful.
And, you know, Neal, it was just amazing to see her at this point because there was confirmation that, yes, you know, we were getting ourselves down, but we were actually going to make it.
You know, once we saw her, it was a huge, huge sigh of relief.
Brad Wieners' story in Sports Illustrated is called ""Countdown to Tragedy."" We're speaking with him and with one of the climbers, Betsy Smith.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's go next to Gene.
And Gene is with us from Fresno in California.
Hello.
How are you, guys?
Good.
Thanks.
Thanks for putting me on the show.
Well, I guess I'm a member of that very elite, however sad, group of being struck by lightning and survived.
I went out.
There was a lighting storm outside of my home in New York when I lived there as a teenager and I went outside to watch it foolishly.
And lightning struck the ground about 10 or 15 feet in front of me.
And like the lady was saying earlier on the call, it was interesting because you don't really feel it immediately.
But I remember every time the flash went off, it felt like maybe, best way to describe it is like a giant, grabbing your body and squeezing you, because your body completely tensed up solid.
And with each flash, it's like bup-budda-bup and you tensed up every time.
And of course, you fall to the ground.
And I couldn't breathe momentarily and stuff.
But it's just - it's like weird, surreal.
Any lasting effects?
Yeah.
You know, more - mostly, whenever there's a lightning storm now, foolishly, I'm a little nervous.
But I don't know.
Medically, I couldn't tell you, but it does have an emotional strain on you, because I do a lot of outdoor activities like your callers there in the mountains.
And when those storms come through, you feel very vulnerable.
So that's the only effect that I can remember that mostly.
Betsy Smith, your lasting effects were a little bit more serious.
They were a bit.
I definitely have the emotional effects that the caller related, of course.
But I lost one of my index fingers, which has actually been the easiest injury to cope with.

And then, you know, I lost quite a bit of muscle tissue and then other, you know, tendons and things underneath that wristwatch burnt, so that when with - I risked the most with losing my hand on that injury.
And thankfully, they were able to keep it on there, so...
So this is going to be with you the rest of your life.
Definitely.
Definitely, it will be.
Let's go next to Dennis.
Dennis with us from Emerson in Michigan.
Yeah.
I got a hit back in about 15 years ago.
And I was on my motorcycle riding to work, got trapped on the storm, took refuge under a pole building.
And, I guess, the building got hit.
It wasn't a direct hit.
And it knocked me out.
I got to work.
And the thing that caught me, it's a little funny - is everybody who's - you're so lucky that you should go play the lottery.
And it was like, well, I just got hit by a lightning, how lucky is that?
Not very in my book.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I hear that all the time.
That you were lucky?
Yes, that I was lucky.
Yeah.
Some luck.
Yeah.
Dennis...
I was...
OK.
Dennis, thanks very much.
Thank you very much.
I wanted to ask Brad Wieners.
How did you get onto this story?
I was actually out at Wyoming to climb the Grand.
And the night before my hike, the guide that was going to take me up to the mountain ran through some of the hazards we might face.
And I have a bit of a fear of heights, so climbing this mountain was largely about facing that fear for me.
And I hadn't really thought about lightning.
And he proceeded to tell me that there was a position we might assume if we couldn't get to safe place and there was lightning.
And I thought he was joking.
I thought that, you know, that's like the old parody of a nuclear strike, where you get down and put your head between your knees and kiss your butt goodbye or something, you know?
But he was actually running me through of some of the very things that Alan and Betsy and their crew did.
You know, they just got rid of your metal and actually - this was interesting too.
Actually, sort of, making a closed-circuit of your body, so bringing your feet together, your ankles together, so that the energy might flash over your body, and not pass through it.
Some listeners may have seen those pictures of all the dead livestock out in fields along the metal fences.
You know, the four-legged creatures are at a serious disadvantage because there's a differential between each of their feet.

So there is a lightning position, and that's - that led to them telling me about this rescue because the rescue involved climbers - the climbing ranger team that prepares for this, but they also drafted the - a couple of the commercial guides who were present at the base camp to help them out.
Betsy Smith, here on now, do you climb?
Uh-huh.
And so what did you do about it?
I do.
I definitely do.
I wasn't able to start climbing again until October of last year after the accident.
And I climbed through the winter and do a little bit of rock climbing now.
I'm a student, so I don't get out on these many weekend trips.
And I'm definitely a little more cautious when it comes to real exposure.
If there is any chance of rain, whatsoever, I'm not going to be out there right now, at least, you know?
It's a much scarier adventure for me.

And, you know, longer climbs, climbs that are going to take days, you know, a full day, two days, I haven't been back on yet just because I don't want to get my team in a position where I get scared and, you know, can't go any further so...
Thanks very much for your time today and good luck.
Thank you for having me, Neal.
And, Brad Wieners, thank you as well.
Thank you, Neal.
Take care.
Brad Wieners is a special contributor to Sports Illustrated.
His piece is called ""Countdown to Tragedy."" Tomorrow, it's TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Ira Flatow will chat with Dean Kamen and will.i.am from the Black Eyed Peas.
They're working together to get kids interested in science.
We'll see you again on Monday.
Have a great weekend, everybody.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
All right, thinning the field in Iowa, well, it's an agricultural state.
Senior Washington editor Ron Elving is here.
Ron, thanks for being with us again.
And where do the candidates stand at now in trying to make sure they're not the one who gets thinned.
What do they do?
They run harder than ever, Alex.

There is currently this wonderful holiday pause where it's the season of peace, and suddenly all the candidates are reminding the other candidates that it's the season of peace and telling them to lay off with the negative ads.
We're going to get about 48 hours of these.
And then on Wednesday, they're going to be back at it in which you try to do is you single out the person who's your biggest problem.
While all the time, of course, attempting to remain above the fray personally and letting your surrogate (unintelligible) in.
The two frontrunners among the Democrats in Iowa, Ron, Senator Clinton, Senator Obama, plainly these are each other's biggest problems.
What do they do?
I think they have to stick with the persona that worked for them best over the last six months.
And in the Obama case, I think he is going to, at least, try to appear to be the idealistic candidate of the future.

And Hillary Clinton, on the other hand, having been overtaken as the once prohibitive frontrunner and favorite, she has to make sure that nobody goes to the caucuses In Iowa wondering if there are real differences between her and Obama, or wondering whether or not there are not some deficiencies on Obama's resume if he is not in some sense or another lacking.
There's a new Boston Globe poll today.
What are the figures is showing?
The new poll shows Obama just the tiniest bit ahead in New Hampshire.
It's within the statistical margin of error.
But it essentially shows that he has overtaken her, not only in Iowa, but in New Hampshire.
And, you know, Alex, I think the Clinton people are looking at some of the polls.

They're looking at the disarray on their Republican side, and they're saying, if we can win Iowa, if we can stop the Obama momentum there, then we can win New Hampshire, and we can go on to Florida at the end of January and really wrap this thing up.
They are seeing Barack Obama right now as the main obstacle between her and the presidency.

Maybe the big item for the Republicans now is simply trying to find someone who might be a frontrunner, a role that was supposed to be filled by either former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani or former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson.
What happened?
Both those candidates have now faded to the point where it's not even clear they're going to be factors.
Rudy Giuliani is not competitive in any January state until we get to January 29th at the very end of the state in Florida.
And Fred Thompson doesn't look competitive anywhere.
You know, Ron, I'm struck by what you're saying here, both about the Democrats and the Republicans that you're seeing a situation that is not what you expected.
It's not what we thought would happen, and I wonder if that tells you anything about politics in 2007 and indeed looking ahead to 2008.

It's very difficult to write a script for the politics of a coming presidential election when the issues are shifting as rapidly as they are -Iraq declining as an issue, economic insecurity taking over for national security as a national preoccupation and when the candidates themselves are running so far out of their expectation.

Mitt Romney, who is supposed to have a chance only if he could win Iowa and New Hampshire, now we see him in trouble in Iowa, in trouble in New Hampshire and yet, with a real chance to recover from a rocky start, if only because the other well-financed candidates - Giuliani, Thompson - have faded out so much.
